ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Amblyaudia
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Extreme asymmetry on Competing Sentences test (Right ear 0-5%, Left ear 90-95%) despite symmetrical hearing thresholds, indicating a deficit in binaural integration with left-ear dominance.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe SNHL explains thresholds and poor performance on low-pass filtered speech, but does not account for the specific binaural interference complaint.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cognitive Decline
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered as a potential contributor to difficulties in noise; memory screening was sufficient for testing, but a referral was made for further cognitive assessment.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear Pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to absent acoustic reflexes, but deemed unlikely given the symmetrical thresholds, lack of rollover, and specific CAP findings.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess word recognition and check for rollover.
Ensure sufficient memory for CAP testing validity.
Assess binaural integration and dichotic listening.
Assess dichotic listening with lower linguistic load.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Re-assessment 1 year post-fitting revealed stable bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss. Word recognition was excellent in quiet with no rollover, reducing the likelihood of retrocochlear pathology despite absent acoustic reflexes. Hearing aids were verified to be functioning correctly and meeting prescriptive targets.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe SNHL, gradually falling configuration (PTA ~33 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent word recognition (100% at 80 dB HL) bilaterally; no rollover observed.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A bilaterally (normal middle ear function).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes at maximum stimulus levels (100 dB HL).

tests.name: Hearing Aid Verification
tests.result_summary: Hearing aids met manufacturer specs and NAL-NL2 REIG targets; remote mic functioning correctly.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Central Auditory Processing (CAP) assessment revealed Amblyaudia, characterized by a severe deficit in binaural integration with marked left-ear dominance on the Competing Sentences test. Other tests showed smaller asymmetries or deficits consistent with SNHL. Memory screening confirmed cognitive ability to complete the battery.

tests.name: Memory Screening
tests.result_summary: Sufficient short-term and working memory to complete CAP testing.

tests.name: Competing Sentences (CS)
tests.result_summary: Extreme asymmetry: Right ear 0-5% (poor), Left ear 90-95% (excellent), indicating Amblyaudia.

tests.name: Two-Pair Dichotic Digits (TPDD)
tests.result_summary: High scores bilaterally (R 82.5%, L 100%) with smaller asymmetry than CS.

tests.name: Low-Pass Filtered Speech (LPFS)
tests.result_summary: Poor performance bilaterally (R 48%, L 44%), consistent with SNHL.

proposed_items: Auditory Rehabilitation for Interaural Asymmetry (ARIA) training (4 sessions over 3 weeks)
Continued use of bilateral hearing aids
Referral to psychologist for cognitive assessment
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of Amblyaudia (brain preference for the left ear) as the cause of 'jumbled' speech in noise
Discuss why removing the right hearing aid sometimes helps (reducing binaural interference)
Counsel on the benefits of remote microphone technology despite cosmetic concerns
Review the outcomes of ARIA training and the need for ongoing monitoring

escalation.rationale_short: To investigate cognitive status as a potential contributor to the limited benefit from hearing aids.

follow_up_plan.objective: Re-assess CAP skills and functional benefit with hearing aids.

expected_outcome: Post-ARIA Competing Sentences (CS): Significant improvement in the nondominant right ear to 30% at 0 dB SNR, 70% at +5 dB SNR, and 90% at +10 dB SNR.
Post-ARIA Two-Pair Dichotic Digits (TPDD): Scores remained high with no significant change (Right 95%, Left 98%).
Post-ARIA Low-Pass Filtered Speech (LPFS): No significant change (Right 36%, Left 56%).
Post-ARIA Frequency Patterns (FP): No significant change (Right 86%, Left 80%).
Patient reported mildly improved benefit when wearing both hearing aids in noisy environments and less stress/exhaustion.
Patient reported fewer occasions of removing one hearing aid in noise but continued to withdraw from some social gatherings.
